Award.AwardTitle: PIRE: Science at the Triple Point Between Mathematics, Mechanics and Materials Science
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many contemporary problems in new advanced materials relate to variation in length, time scales, and variations inherent in their fabrication and function. Resolution of these problems requires predictive theories for these complex systems that in turn require advances in mathematics. In this PIRE project an international network of prominent mathematicians from four U.S. institutions, five European institutions, and a multinational industrial partner, will build on decades of collaboration and training at the interface of mathematics and materials sciences that have yielded many achievements at the forefront of sophisticated new mathematics and simulation methods. The project will focus on four principal research areas: 1. Pattern formation from energy minimization, 2. Challenges in atomistic to continuum modelling and computing, 3. Prediction of hysteresis (systems that have "memory" such that effects of stimuli are temporally delayed), and 4. Pattern dynamics and development of material microstructure.

U.S. and European students will benefit from internationalized education and research training within a PIRE framework promotes new patterns in research collaboration and education that includes cultural dimensions. Advanced graduate courses will be developed and shared across the network providing a truly internationalized curriculum and universal access to the best materials-relevant mathematics topics. U.S. graduate students and postdoctoral fellows will be immersed in intensive multi-advisor mentoring models strengthening their interdisciplinary and global research skills. Interested graduate students will be able to partake in an international industrial research internship. In addition, annual workshops and summer schools will extend the research to a much wider community of students and postdoctoral fellows outside the project.

This award will help to internationalize US institutions by linking them in a vibrant international network of applied mathematicians who integrate research relevant to materials science with a coherent program for training the next generation of globally-engaged scientific leaders in fast-developing areas of mathematics. The complementary strengths and expertise of the team will push the frontiers of applied analysis and clear the pathway for new applications in materials research. The U.S. will gain expertise and strength in the field of calculus of variations, essential to the first principal research area, through its base at two of the European research centers. Working with European partners will help unify and extend U.S. expertise in the modelling, computation, and analysis on problems arising in materials science. Advances in pattern dynamics research at several nodes of the network have revealed new modelling and analysis opportunities with the potential to be leveraged by this award.

Collaborators on this PIRE project include four U.S. institutions: Carnegie Mellon University (PA), California Institute of Technology, New York University, and University of Minnesota; five European institutions: University of Antwerp (Belgium), University of Bonn (Germany), Max Planck Institute for Mathematics in the Sciences (Germany), International School for Advanced Studies (SISSA)(Italy), and University of Oxford (UK); and an industrial partner: Robert Bosch GmbH (Germany and USA).

This project is supported by NSF's Office of International Science and Engineering and the Division of Mathematical Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This PIRE project was a NSF-funded international collaboration program which ran from January 2011-September 2017.

There were four US nodes

  • Carnegie Mellon University (CMU)

  • California Institute of Technology (Caltech)

  • University of Minnesota

  • New York University (NYU)

and seven foreign partners

  • University of Antwerp, Belgium

  • University of Bonn, Germany

  • Max Planck Institute for Mathematics in the Sciences (MPI), Leipzig, Germany

  • University of Oxford, United Kingdom

  • SISSA. International School for Advanced Studies, Italy

  • University of Warwick, United Kingdom

  • Robert Bosch Corporation, Germany

This PIRE project had three different types of goals, involving (i) science, (ii) education, and (iii) networking. These goals are interconnected and inter-dependent.

The scientific goal was to lead applied analysis to new frontiers and promote pathways to new applications, using the complementary strengths and combined expertise of the PIRE team. Specific research topics were at the boundaries where nonlinear partial differential equations, and the calculus of variations meet materials science and mechanics. The four scientific themes, all at the interface where PDE and the calculus of variations meet mechanics and materials science, were

  • Pattern formation from energy minimization. Here a major focus is the emergence of microstructure. Examples of microstructure in physical systems include the twinning associated with a martensitic phase transformation, vortex patterns in type-II superconductors, wrinkle patterns in thin elastic sheets under tension, and blister patterns in compressed thin films on elastic substrates. Such problems have traditionally been addressed by minimizing the relevant energy either numerically or within an ansatz. A more global and mathematically complete understanding was obtained by studying how the minimum energy scales with the physical parameters, and exploring the properties of energy minimizing patterns.

  • Challenges in atomistic to continuum modeling and computing. Crystal defects such as grain boundaries, cracks, or dislocations play a central role in determiningmaterial behavior, and their study represents a substantial component of materials science research. Molecular simulation provides a unique way to study complex material behavior at the nanoscale, in particular how defects affect macroscopic processes such as elasticity, plasticity, and fracture. The key difficulty in atomistic simulation is that crystal defects affect elastic fields far beyond their immediate atomic neighborhood; that is, they give rise to strongly coupled multiscale systems. By employing coarse discretizations (e.g., finite elements) of the continuum elasticity model a considerable reduction in computational complexity compared to full atomistic descriptions was achieved.

  • Prediction of hysteresis. This study should be contrasted with most of the previous work on mathematical models of hysteresis that were mainly concerned with the modeling of hysteresis loops but did not provide an explanation for the origins of hysteresis in terms of precisely identifiable material properties or microstructural features. Our work led to significant progress toward this goal, by revealing the dominating role of geometry in controlling hysteresis. Briey, the precise fitting together of phases, using energy minimizing states, while avoiding stressed transition layers, emerged as the central concept in this field.

  • Pattern dynamics and evolution of material microstructure. The energetics and connectivity of cellular and granular networks and the boundary network during evolution play a crucial role in determining the properties of a material across a wide range of scales. One view is that patterns are stable statistics of metastable systems. The identification and validation of such statistics are used for predictive theories. This was accomplished using analytic and numerical tools.

Over 130 publications appearing in international journals resulted from this PIRE project.

The educational goal was to to educate and train globally competent young researchers and to prepare them to pursue academic/research positions at US institutions. PIRE students and postdocswill gained breadth and international experience through travel, networking, and interaction with scientists at nodes other than their home institutions. US-based students and postdocs acquired mentors at foreign partner institutions, and spent semesters abroad. A total of 14 Postdoctoral Fellows and 11 Ph.D students were trained under this program.

The networking goal was to increase the frequency and coherence of communication between investigators at the various PIRE nodes. This was achieved through summer schools, workshops, mobility of researchers and trainees between US and foreign nodes. The PIRE research and training activities were extended to the wider scientific community through workshops and summerschools There were 2 summer schools (U. of Minnesota and CMU) and 5 Workshops (Oxford, SISSA, Warwick, MPI, and NYU). Additional scientific activities included

  • Advanced topics courses

  • Working groups

  • Visitors' program

  • Weekly Seminar series

  • Outreach activities: Summer Undergraduate Applied Mathematics Institute (SUAMI)

The success of the program was annually assessed by an external evaluator using data collected via targeted surveys.
